newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's Old Mutual fund bullish on UK assets.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's Old Mutual fund bullish on UK assets.

text.p: Old Mutual, South Africa's biggest life assurer, said on Thursday that a surge in the value of British assets was set to continue.

Hilary Wakefield, global portfolio manager at UK-based Old Mutual International Asset Managers, said British assets -- including property, equity and sterling -- would benefit from low inflation, a current account surplus, modest wage increases and company profit growth.

"Gilts have recovered their earlier price losses, but have yet to share fully in Europe's price gains. Equities and property are performing more strongly as evidence of economic growth accumulates," he told a news briefing in Johannesburg.
But the British economy, in its fifth year of recovery, still lacks a firm base of a consumer "feel-good" factor.
"This may be due to the moderate nature of the recovery, which is the very quality that makes it impressive to economists," Wakefield said.
Wakefield was less bullish about the prospects for U.S. markets, which have enjoyed a sustained bull run that is still breaking records.

On Wednesday U.S. stocks jumped to new highs as investors bet newly re-elected President Bill Clinton and the Republican-retained Congress would keep the economy growing, propelling corporate earnings higher.
But Wakefield said Wall Street stocks were overvalued.
"We believe that U.S. equities are vulnerable, given an expected economic slowdown and possible interest rate hikes," he said.
